citation.article-title: Paracoccus bengalensis sp. nov., a novel sulfur-oxidizing chemolithoautotroph from the rhizospheric soil of an Indian tropical leguminous plant.

p.s: Description of the species P. bengalensis
P. bengalensis (ben.gal.enśis. N.L. masc. adj. bengalensis of Bengal, after the name of the province West Bengal of India from where the bacterium was isolated.)
Gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming bacterium having coccoidal or irregularly elliptical cells with a major axis of 0.8–1.0 μm and minor axis of 0.5–0.7 μm.
Colonies on LA or MSTY medium are creamy white, convex and opaque.
Maximum temperature for growth is 37 °C and range of pH tolerance is 5.0–8.5.
It has respiratory metabolism with oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor but can also grow anaerobically with nitrate as the electron acceptor in heterotrophic medium.
Growth in synthetic media, particularly chemoorganotrophic growth on single carbon-compounds, requires some yet unknown growth factor that is satisfied by 50 mg l−1 of yeast extract.
The bacterium is catalase, oxidase and denitrification positive; cannot liquefy gelatin, produce indole or solubilize phosphate.

The organism is a facultative chemolithoautotroph and can grow on thiosulfate, tetrathionate, soluble sulfide and elemental sulfur as the sole energy and electron source but not on thiocyanate or sulfite.
The bacterium can grow chemoorganoheterotrophically in complex media like Luria–Bertani broth, nutrient broth or minimal mineral salts plus peptone casein hydrolyzate.

In synthetic media supplemented with 50 mg l−1 of yeast extract or vitamin mixture the organism can utilize d-glucose, d-fructose, d-raffinose, d-galactose, d-lactose, l-arabinose, l-glutamine, sodium benzoate, glycerol, maltose, sucrose, malate, succinate, acetate, mannitol, l-histidine, l-leucine, l-isoleucine and l-glutamine as single substrates for chemoorganoheterotrophic growth.

Formate, rhamnose, citrate, oxalate, mandelate, adipate, aesculin, phenylacetate, dl-lactate, d-mannose, d-xylose, l-glutamate, l-aspartate, l-alanine, l-serine, l-lysine, l-cysteine, l-cystine, l-tyrosine, l-threonine and l-arginine are not utilized.
Urea, nitrate and ammonium salts are utilized as nitrogen sources while aspartate and glutamate are not.

The bacterium synthesizes the following fatty acids: Summed feature 2 (16:1 iso I & 14:0 3-OH) (2.86%), Summed feature 3 (16:1ω7c & 15:0 iso 2-OH) (0.37%), 16:0 (6.02%), 18:1ω7c (76.96%), 18:0 (1.09%), 19:0 10 methyl (0.28%), 19:0 cycloω8c (6.78%), 10:0 3-OH (2.80%) and unknown fatty acid of ECL∼11.8 (2.85%).
The G+C content of the only strain JJJT of this monotypic species, as determined by HPLC is 65.3 mol%.

JJJT (=LMG 22700T=MTCC 7003T) the only known strain (thus the type strain) of the species has been isolated from soil adjacent to the roots of the plant Clitoria ternatea, a native legume of the lower-Gangetic plains of India, particularly West Bengal.
